Everything ephemeral was once someone's whole world

Hand-etched wax seals of equations nobody remembered, from chalkboards nobody photographed, in chapels nobody prayed in.

A Letter From the Founder

or: why I sell grief at markup

My grandfather was a mathematician. Not the kind who wins prizes — the kind who fills chapel chalkboards during airport layovers because his flight got delayed and he couldn't stop thinking about eigenvalues. He died at Denver International in 1989. Gate B31. Nobody kept a single thing he wrote.

I started Nostalgia Vaporwave because I wanted to sell the feeling of missing something that was never yours to begin with. Every wax seal we etch is a wrong equation — not wrong because we can't do math, but wrong because memory is wrong. You don't remember the formula. You remember the chalk dust.

We are not an art collective. We are not a candle company with delusions. We are a very small operation that hand-pours grief into hot wax and stamps it with the ghost of someone's unfinished proof.

(Bromley was here for the first three years. He handled logistics, which mostly meant arguing with the USPS about whether a wax seal counts as "fragile." He left in 2021. I don't know where he is. His phone number works but he never answers. I keep his name on the About page because removing it would feel like another thing that didn't survive long enough to matter.)

The equations are wrong. The prices are absurd. The shipping is calculated by your astrological sign. None of this is ironic. All of it is true.

The Collective

Bjorn Halvstad

Former thermodynamics lecturer turned wax artisan. Quit academia in 2014 after realizing he'd spent eleven years teaching a room full of people who would never once think about entropy while waiting for a delayed flight. Now he does. Every single day.

~bjorn/waxworks.geocities.com (offline since 2019)
Marguerite Chen-Okafor

Ash's cousin, though they didn't speak for most of the 2010s. Makes the equation stencils by hand using a magnifying glass and a very old X-Acto knife. Has described her creative process as "controlled grieving with better lighting."

~marguerite_chen/art.geocities.com (404)
Deck Muñoz

Handles the wax itself — sourcing, mixing, temperature. Believes that paraffin above 67°C "remembers differently." Will not elaborate. Previously ran a failed candle subscription service called Terminal Velocity Aromatics. No one subscribed.

~deck_m/candles.geocities.com (seized by angelfire)

Frequently Asked & Reluctantly Answered

Yes. Every equation on every seal is wrong in at least one way. Sometimes it's a transposed variable. Sometimes it's a sign error. Sometimes it's technically correct but written in a notation that no living mathematician would recognize, because we reconstructed it from a photograph of a photograph of a chalkboard that was erased in 1991.

The wrongness is the point. Your memory of your grandmother's phone number is wrong too. You still dial it sometimes.

Because zip codes are a lie invented by the postal service to make you think distance is real. Your wax seal knows where it needs to go. Mercury's position relative to your natal chart determines the vibrational urgency of delivery. Scorpios always pay more because Scorpios always pay more. This is not a bug. This is astrology working exactly as intended — which is to say, not at all, but with tremendous confidence.

Actual answer: Bromley set it up as a joke in 2018 and I never changed the code because every time I try to make the shipping rational, something else on the site breaks. The astrology stays.

Yes, but you have to tell us the story first. Not the equation — the story. Where you saw it, who was holding the chalk, what the room smelled like, whether the fluorescent lights were buzzing. Marguerite needs the context to get the mistakes right. The mistakes are specific. A misremembered integral from a lecture hall in Bruges is different from a misremembered integral from a hospital whiteboard in Tulsa. She can tell. She will know if you're lying.

Custom commissions start at $600 and take 4-8 weeks. We've done nine. Three of the people cried when they opened the package. One sent it back because it was "too accurate." We refunded her and kept the seal in a drawer labeled UNBEARABLE.

Last I heard, he was in a town outside Reykjavik doing something with geothermal energy, which is very funny because Bromley once described Iceland as "a place that exists only to make you feel small." He sent me a postcard in March 2022 — no return address, just a drawing of a wax seal with no equation on it. I pinned it to the corkboard above the packing station.

Bromley believed in the project more than I did, at the beginning. He was the one who said "the equations have to be wrong or it's just merch." He was right about that. He was right about most things except the part where he thought he could leave quietly and I wouldn't notice the shape of the absence.

If you're reading this, Brom: the USPS still doesn't classify wax seals as fragile. I check every quarter. Your mug is still on the shelf. The chai's gone stale but I haven't thrown it out. I'm not asking you to come back. I'm asking you to answer the phone once.
